content.title: Natural History of Untreated Peripheral Arterial Disease

statement.text: The natural history of PAD demonstrates relatively benign limb outcomes but significantly elevated cardiovascular mortality, with only 1-3% annual progression to critical limb ischemia but 20-30% mortality at 5 years.
statement.formal: Annual progression rate to CLTI: 1-3%; 5-year mortality: 20-30%; major amputation in claudicants: <5% at 5 years

explanation.intuition: PAD is primarily a marker of systemic atherosclerosis. While local limb symptoms may remain stable, the underlying disease process affects coronary and cerebral vessels, making cardiovascular death far more likely than limb loss.
explanation.key_insight: The leg will likely survive, but the patient may not - cardiovascular risk reduction is more important than limb intervention for most claudicants.
explanation.technical_details: Population studies including the Edinburgh Artery Study and PARTNERS program demonstrate that among patients with intermittent claudication, symptom stability or improvement occurs in approximately 75% over 5 years. Only 1-3% annually progress to chronic limb-threatening ischemia (CLTI). However, 5-year mortality rates of 20-30% and cardiovascular event rates of 20% highlight the systemic nature of atherosclerotic disease.
common_misconceptions: Claudication inevitably leads to amputation - FALSE, only 1-2% of claudicants require major amputation at 5 years
Bypass surgery is needed for all PAD patients - FALSE, most claudicants can be managed medically
PAD is primarily a limb problem - FALSE, it is a marker of systemic atherosclerosis with high cardiac mortality

treatment_priorities: Cardiovascular risk reduction takes precedence over limb revascularization
Smoking cessation is mandatory for all PAD patients
Aggressive statin therapy regardless of baseline cholesterol
intervention_thresholds: Claudication alone: Medical therapy and exercise first
Lifestyle-limiting claudication: Consider intervention after medical optimization
CLTI (rest pain, tissue loss): Urgent revascularization needed

definition.@value: The characteristic progression of peripheral arterial disease without intervention, marked by relatively stable limb outcomes but significantly elevated cardiovascular mortality.

presentation: Intermittent claudication with predictable walking distance
Symptom stability in most patients over time
treatment: Revascularization reserved for lifestyle limitation or CLTI

sources.reference: Edinburgh Artery Study natural history cohort

learning_objectives: Describe the 5-year limb and survival outcomes for patients with claudication
Explain why cardiovascular risk reduction is prioritized over limb intervention
Identify predictors of progression from claudication to CLTI
Apply natural history data to patient counseling and treatment planning
clinical_pearls: The leg will survive, but the patient may not - CV mortality >> amputation risk
Only 1-3% of claudicants progress to CLTI annually
5-year mortality is 20-30%, mostly from cardiac events
Diabetics and smokers have worst progression rates
ABI <0.50 predicts higher limb event risk
